Key Laboratory ofAuthor Special Functional Materials for Ecological Environment and Information (Hebei University of Technology), Ministry of Education Tianjin 300130 China Electrocatalytic CO2RR is an ideal method. It is capable of converting CO2 into usable fuels and valuable chemical products. Electrocatalytic CO2RR produces a wide range of chemicals. Of these, ethanol (EtOH) is favored for its wide industrial and commercial value. However, electrocatalytic CO2RR preparation of EtOH involves C-C coupling reactions and is a multi-electron transfer process. For this reason, the efficient electrochemical conversion of EtOH by CO2RR remains a great challenge. The preparation of EtOH by electrocatalytic CO2RR involves the interference of a competing hydrogen evolution reaction as well as some other reaction intermediates. This limits the improvement of Faraday efficiency of ethanol (FEEtOH) and the current density of ethanol (JEtOH). To improve ethanol selectivity, the researchers designed and modified the catalysts using engineering regulation effects such as reaction conditions engineering regulation, surface engineering regulation, interfacial engineering regulation, and single atom engineering regulation, and achieved excellent results. Therefore, it is important to understand the key factors affecting the catalyst activity by different engineering regulations and to apply a combination of engineering regulations to the catalyst development. Therefore, this paper firstly provides a comprehensive summary of the catalysts applied for the preparation of EtOH by electrocatalytic CO2RR, including two major categories of catalysts containing pure metal active components and catalysts without pure metal active components. Subsequently, the main effects of engineering modulation on catalyst activity are analyzed and summarized in detail, respectively. Finally, the future challenges and development prospects of electrocatalytic CO2RR for EtOH preparation were highlighted. Graphical Abstract Keywords Electrocatalytic CO2RR Engineering regulation Reaction conditions engineering Surface Engineering Interfacial engineering Single atom engineering Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 introduction The use of fossil fuels has led to technological development and improved living conditions. However, the large-scale use of fossil fuels has led to an increase in the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which ultimately contributes to the greenhouse effect. The greenhouse effect has led to many environmental problems such as the melting of the Antarctic ice sheet [1]. For this reason, the importance of controlling and reducing the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has been recognized. A number of solutions have been proposed to address rising carbon dioxide levels. For example, reducing the use of fossil fuels and capturing and sequestering carbon dioxide. Notably, it is the conversion of CO2 into useful chemicals that is most attractive in these approaches [2]. In particular, converting excess carbon dioxide into high-value-added chemical products and energy is a double win. It closes the natural carbon cycle and enables the sustainable use of energy while mitigating the greenhouse effect [3–7]. Currently, electrocatalytic CO2RR, which can convert carbon dioxide into valuable chemical raw materials, has attracted much attention [8,9]. Among the products produced by the electrocatalytic CO2RR reaction ethanol is favored for its high energy density (29.7 MJ kg−1) and transport safety [10–12]. This gives it a wide range of industrial applications and a large market demand. For this reason, the preparation of ethanol from electrocatalytic CO2RR not only reduces CO2 emissions but also brings economic benefits. However, electrocatalytic CO2RR involves multiple proton-coupled electron transfer processes as well as C-C coupling reactions ( Fig. 1a-b), making the improvement of ethanol faraday efficiency (FEEtOH) and ethanol current density (JEtOH) limited [13–17]. In order to improve the selectivity of ethanol, the researchers designed and modified the catalysts using engineering regulation effects such as surface engineering regulation, interfacial engineering regulation and single-atom engineering regulation, and the reaction conditions engineering regulation of the electrolyte, which achieved good results ( Scheme 1, Fig. 1c). The engineered catalysts showed several improvements: (i) the selectivity of the catalysts was improved mainly due to the engineering effect which resulted in lowering the formation barriers of the key intermediates, (ii) the increase of carbon dioxide adsorption, and (iii) the increase of catalyst stability. These three aspects have led to an increase in catalyst selectivity. At the same time, statistics show that most catalysts can be divided into two main categories: catalysts with pure metal active components and catalysts without pure metal active components. In this paper, we will review these two types of catalysts, through engineering effects such as reaction condition engineering, surface engineering, interfacial engineering and single-atom engineering, to study in detail the effects of these two types of catalysts on catalytic activity, and to summaries the problems and solutions that are still being faced in the production of ethanol by electrocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide. 2 Reaction conditions engineering regulation It is well known that the reaction conditions (added electrolyte, pH, applied potential and temperature) for the preparation of ethanol by electrocatalytic CO2RR have a great influence on the improvement of reaction selectivity [19,20]. It is worth noting that the preparation of ethanol from electrocatalytic CO2RR involves a multi-step reaction [13]. For this reason, being able to precisely regulate the reaction bar is essential to reduce unwanted side reactions. A detailed review of the effects of different reaction conditions on the selective generation of EtOH from CO2RR is presented below. 2.1 Electrolyte and pH condition Firstly, the effect of the electrolyte is discussed. Ionic liquids (ILs) as anisotropic fluids have the unique property of extended supramolecular-like networks. This gives them a different reaction mechanism compared to aqueous solutions. The role of ILs is mainly twofold: firstly, adsorption of CO2, and secondly, stabilization of CO2 - [21]. Meanwhile, CO2 exists in ionic liquids in two forms the first one is physisorption ( Fig. 2a) and the second one is chemisorption (Fig. 2b). Physical adsorption occurs mainly in ionic liquids with nucleophilic anions such as bis(trifluoromethyl)sulfonamide. It is worth noting that this weak interaction does not break will not break the hydrogen bonding interactions between cation-anion in ionic liquids. Chemisorption of CO2 occurs mainly through carboxylation of CO2, which is further converted to bicarbonate in the process of carboxylation. This CO2 adsorption is observed in ionic liquids containing acidic protons and basic anions (e.g., acetate and imidazole) in proton-rich media [22]. Most ionic liquids are viscous（Fig. 2c）, which restricts the movement of charged ions and thus the transport of protons and electrons [23]. Therefore, the ionic liquids are usually diluted with water to optimize proton and electron transport, leading to enhanced proton utilization and increased CO2 reduction rates. The disadvantages of ionic liquids are also apparent, they are expensive and environmentally toxic. It is well known that the preparation of ethanol by electrocatalytic CO2RR belongs to a multi-step proton coupled electron transfer reaction (PCET) [26,27]. The PCET process is influenced to some extent by the properties of the electrolyte. Thus, regulating the nature of the electrolyte may be useful to improve the selectivity of ethanol [28]. On the basis of the above, Sun et al. [25] systematically investigated the effect of electrolytes on the catalytic system. They applied a commercial indium electrode in combination with a range of electrolytes (Keggin POM (PVnMo(12-n)O40)) to the electrocatalytic CO2RR preparation of ethanol. The experiments were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy as well as cyclic voltammetry and it was found that POM acted as an activator of CO2. It is well known that the PCET process undergoes electrode oxidation reaction to some extent. This results in the oxidation of In0, which ultimately leads to the weakening of *CO adsorption. Notably, the reduction of V in the combined POM-In system resulted in the retention of the active site of In0 to promote the subsequent reaction of *CO. In this regard, the combined POM-In system not only increased the activation of CO2 but also inhibited the oxidation of the electrode to a certain extent, thus promoting the efficient reaction (Fig. 2d). Meanwhile, Sun et al. investigated the relationship between pH and the electrochemical behavior of POM and found that the change of redox sites was linearly related to the pH shift. This result suggests that electron transfer is accompanied by proton transfer. Thus, it indicates that the POM-In electrocatalytic system can promote both electron and proton transfer. Ultimately, the mass transfer potential is reduced and the selectivity of ethanol is improved. The usual electrolyte environment for electrocatalytic CO2RR is neutral or alkaline, mainly because the alkaline condition promotes the activation of CO2 and facilitates the C-C coupling reaction. The neutral electrolysis is more concerned with the stability of the catalyst [29,30]. It is worth noting that CO2 undergoes different transformations in alkaline environments. At a pH of 7–10, CO2 is converted to HCO3 - and converts to CO3 2- as the pH continues to rise ( Fig. 3a) [31]. Since this conversion is thermodynamically very favorable, the conversion is rapid and reacts with a large amount of electrogenerated OH- during this period (Fig. 3b), which can result in carbon and product losses at high current densities. The acidic electrolyte, on the other hand, can substantially increase the efficiency of CO2 utilization and reduce the cost of product separation [32]. Currently, membrane electrode assemblies are often combined with polymer membranes containing acidic functional groups to be used as acidic electrolytes (Fig. 3c-d) Such membrane devices allow only H3O+ and metal cations to migrate, avoiding the formation of (bis)carbonates and thus eliminating the carbon deposition effect. The pH of the electrolyte is related to many factors, such as the composition of the electrolyte, buffering capacity, and operating conditions. Notably, the pH of the electrolyte plays a key role in regulating the CO2RR overpotential, reaction rate, and product distribution [33,34]. A study of CO2RR product distribution in different pH electrolyte environments revealed that alkaline electrolytes are conducive to CO2 activation and can inhibit HER side reactions; however, the presence of low CO2 utilization and the generation of carbonates can reduce the stability of the catalyst [35]. The CO2RR reaction in an acidic electrolyte can well avoid the above problems. However, conducting CO2RR reaction in a purely acidic electrolyte (pH<1) reaction environment promotes the occurrence of HER side reactions. This problem can be solved by adding cations to the acidic electrolyte to slow down the mobility of H protons to the catalyst surface, thus inhibiting the occurrence of HER side reactions and thus improving the activity and selectivity of CO2RR [36–38]. The effect of specific cations on CO2RR was first identified by Paik et al. [39], but the exact mechanism remains controversial, with three theories commonly proposed: (1) modulation of the interfacial electric field distribution; (2) buffering of the local pH by cation hydrolysis reactions; and (3) stabilization of the reaction intermediates by electrostatic interactions or ligand effects [40,41]. Theoretical calculations and in situ/operando characterization provide intuitive insights into the effects of local pH, cationic additives on acidic electrolysis, and thus help to understand these effects mechanistically. 2.2 Applied potential and reaction temperature The development of electrocatalytic CO2RR for the preparation of ethanol has been hampered by selectivity limitations. Initially, people were devoted to the modification of electrodes, including the surface modification of Cu electrodes [18,42,43]. However, these methods tended to make the electrodes less cycle stable. Remarkably, the use of a pulsed electrochemical potential was able to improve the selectivity of CO2RR products without changing the properties of the electrode [44]. For this reason, the method has attracted attention. For the applied potential of the reaction, a continuous potential is usually used, but Tang et al. [44] intentionally changed the potential input by using a pulsed potential copper foil as the reaction potential for ethanol preparation by CO2RR. Comparison of the reactions showed that the use of pulsed potentials substantially increased the selectivity of the C2 product ( Fig. 4a-b). This is primarily due to the fact that the input of pulsed potential promotes carbon coupling and simultaneously inhibits the manufacture of other CO2RR and HER products (Fig. 4c). It is noteworthy that at ambient temperatures at pulsed potential input conditions the products are mainly C2H2. However slightly changing the reaction temperature the distribution of the products seems to change. For this reason, Tang carried out an exploration of the product distribution at different reaction temperatures (Fig. 4d) and found that the increase or decrease in temperature affects the distribution of the products. The former favors the production of ethylene, while the latter favors the production of ethanol. A possible reason for this is that at lower temperatures the Cu(I) species are more effectively stabilized, thus favoring oxygen adsorption. The analyses show that the substance that produces C2H5OH is Cu(I), while the active site for C2H4 production is the reduced Cu face. Although both Cu(0) and Cu(I) can support C-C coupling, the former is more favorable for C2H4 formation while the latter is more favorable for C2H5OH formation. Briefly, the pulsed potential substantially increases the C2 product at room temperature due to its ability to inhibit other CO2RR and HER products. Lowering the reaction temperature stabilizes the Cu(I) species more effectively, thus favoring oxygen adsorption and making ethanol the main product of the reaction. In addition, Cai et al. [45] found that the pulse potential method could form a Cu(I)/Cu(0) interface model catalyst, and the catalyst mass was in synchronous change with the pulse potential ( Fig. 5a-b). The mass of the catalysts varied synchronously with the pulse potential, which was shown as an increase in mass at the anodic potential and a decrease in mass at the cathodic potential (Fig. 5c-d). Combined with theoretical calculations and analyses, it was shown that the mass change was caused by the redox of copper at the Cu(0)/Cu2OF interface site under the pulse potential. This redox reaction shapes the structural model of the Cu(I)/Cu(0) interface with Cu(0) as the core and Cu(I) as the shell layer (Fig. 5e). As a comparison, Cu(OH)2 at the pulse potential then generated a pure Cu(0) structure, indicating that the F ion is a key factor in stabilising the Cu(I) structure. By analysing the selectivity of ethylene and ethanol, it was found that ethanol is more sensitive to the Cu(I)/Cu(0) ratio, which suggests that ethanol is mainly produced at the interface. Adjusting the Cu(I)/Cu(0) ratio achieves an ethanol Faraday efficiency of 35.4 %, which is 3.6 times higher than that of Cu. In turn, the corresponding ethanol partial current density reaches 128 mA/cm2, which is 18.5 times higher than that of Cu. Analyzing the selectivity of ethylene shows that ethylene has a good basis for production at the Cu(0) site. And the selectivity of ethylene increases with increasing Cu(I) content, which proves that ethylene may be insensitive to Cu(I) and Cu(0), or the synergistic effect of Cu(I) and Cu(0) enhances the selectivity of ethylene. Overall, Cux/Cu2OF exhibits better properties for multicarbon products, including ethylene, ethanol and acetic acid. In summary, the improved selectivity of the CO2RR ethanol product of the multistep proton-coupled electron transfer process (PECT) by the introduction of an electrolyte is attributed to the ability of the electrolyte itself to adsorb the reactant CO2 by its electron-transferring behavior as well as to the retention of the electrode's active site. It is noteworthy that the electron transfer process of the electrolyte is accompanied by proton transfer thus lowering the H+ mass transfer barrier. At the same time, the addition of electrolytes plays a key role in increasing CO2 solubility. Notably, the pH of the electrolyte plays a key role in regulating the CO2RR overpotential, reaction rate and product distribution. The pulsing of the applied potential can effectively inhibit the generation of CO2RR products other than C2 products as well as the HER reaction, thus improving the C2 product selectivity. It is noteworthy that under the pulsed potential, the temperature can modulate the selectivity of C2H2 and EtOH. EtOH generation is favored at low temperatures, whereas C2H2 generation is favored at room temperatures. 3 Engineering regulation of CO2RR catalysts for selective generation of EtOH At present, a wide variety of catalysts are applied to the preparation of ethanol by electrocatalytic CO2RR. As shown in Scheme 2, this article classifies the catalysts into two categories: the first category is the catalysts containing pure metal active components (monometallic and multimetallic); and the second category is the catalysts without pure metal active components (metal oxides and metal sulfide). At the same time, the effects of engineering regulation on each category of catalysts are described in detail and the mechanism of engineering regulation on catalytic activity is investigated in depth. 3.1 Catalysts containing pure metal active centers As shown in Table 1, pure metal active center catalyst refers to the preparation of catalysts containing pure metal active components, which play a key role in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to ethanol. In many studies, the pure metal active center catalysts are mainly Cu [18,42,43,46,47–55], followed by Ag [26,56–59], Au [28,60,61], Fe [27], Sn [62], In [19], and so on. It is noteworthy that most of the many catalysts containing pure metal active centers are closely associated with Cu-based catalysts. Overall Cu-based catalysts are predominant among catalysts containing pure metal active centers. This is attributed to its favorable adsorption of *CO [63,64], thus facilitating the subsequent C-C coupling to form key intermediates [20]. However, there are some problems with pure copper catalysts (e.g., poor C2 selectivity, lower CO2RR activity, and more serious side reaction HER) [65,66]. For this reason, the pure copper catalyst is difficult to be used as an ideal catalyst for the industrialization of electrocatalytic CO2RR. It needs to be combined with other active components or carriers by engineering regulations to improve the selectivity as well as the activity of electrocatalytic CO2 for ethanol preparation. For this reason, the catalysts containing pure metal active components are further subdivided into monometallic and multimetallic catalysts in the following, so that the effect of engineering regulations on catalyst activity is reviewed in detail. 3.1.1 Catalysts containing pure metal active centers-monometallic 3.1.1.1 Surface engineering regulation Surface regulation, on the other hand, is the process of adding other components to the surface of a catalyst with low activity or low selectivity to enhance its catalytic activity or selectivity. As the original catalyst is added with other components, it usually exhibits unique functions which are mainly classified into three categories: (i) HER inhibitors, which are usually modified by organic substances to increase the hydrophobicity of the catalyst, (ii) key intermediate stabilizers, which enhance the stability of the intermediates in the process of ethanol formation from CO2RR due to the surface engineering of the catalysts, and thus are more conducive to the formation of ethanol, (iii) mass transfer enhancers, where the surface modification of the catalyst changes the catalyst's morphology and increases the mass transfer effect during the reaction, thus favoring the carbon coupling during the CO2RR ( Scheme 3). 3.1.1.2 Surface engineering regulation-HER inhibitors One of the problems faced in the preparation of ethanol by CO2RR is the HER competition reaction which results in lower ethanol selectivity [13,14]. The HER competition reaction occurs mainly due to the presence of water in the reaction medium, and therefore, dealing with this problem from the perspective of surface hydrophobicity has become the starting point for many researchers [18,48,50]. Wang et al. [48] prepared a Cu-CuBr-DDT catalyst by modifying Cu using Br- and dodecanethiol (DDT). The high ethanol selectivity of the catalyst was achieved due to the formation of a Br-doped Cu-thiol interface on the catalyst surface ( Fig. 6a). The DDT-treated Cu surface is unfavorable for *H adsorption, thus inhibiting the HER reaction as well as other by-products. It is worth noting that the Br-treated Cu surface changes the electronic structure of Cu to some extent (e.g., formation of Cu with positive valence due to charge compensation). The change in the electronic structure of the catalyst surface affects the distribution of the products and ultimately improves the ethanol selectivity (Fig. 6a). There are times when superhydrophobic interfaces can be constructed by introducing hydrophobic agents through surface engineering. Inspired by the gas-trapping cuticle structure of underwater spiders (Fig. 6b), Wakerley et al. [18] produced a superhydrophobic surface by treating hierarchically structured copper dendrites with 1-octadecanethiol. The production efficiency for ethanol was 17 % at neutral pH, compared to a Faraday efficiency of only 4 % for a hydrophilic, wettable catalyst. Dendritic Cu modified with 1- octadecanethiol formed a multiphase interface (Fig. 6c). The formation of the multiphase interface reduces the precipitation of CO2 compared to the unmodified Cu electrode. This increases the concentration of CO2 at the electrode surface. This is a key factor in improving the product selectivity. Zhao et al. [50] carried out a similar work and further explored the effect of hydrophobic dosage on catalyst performance. They found that the formation of hydrophobic layer facilitates CO2 mass transfer, which promotes CO2RR. however, the addition of excessive hydrophobic agent causes the hydrophobic layer to collapse, which ultimately reduces the CO2RR performance (Fig. 6d). 3.1.1.3 Surface engineering regulation-stabilizer for intermediates The two C2 products, ethylene (C2H4) and EtOH are often generated for CO2RR. Meanwhile, in the CO2RR process, both EtOH and C2H4 are 12 e- reduced species and sharing the initial intermediate *HCCOH [18]. EtOH has a more saturated structure compared to C2H4, and for this reason, it is more difficult to stabilize EtOH's key intermediate on the catalyst surface. As a result, EtOH will be very unfavorable in terms of competing with the C2H4 generation. This typically results in yields of EtOH that are 2–3 times lower than C2H4 on Cu-based catalysts [73–76]. For this reason, stabilization of the key intermediates in the generation of EtOH is critical to improve its selectivity. The strength of catalyst surface adsorption of electrocatalytic CO2RR intermediate species (*HCCOH and *CO) is affected by the catalyst surface structure and electronic effects [77–79]. For this reason, the adsorption of reaction intermediates can be enhanced to some extent by modifying the catalyst surface and thus changing the morphology or electronic structure of the catalyst surface. Ultimately, the product selectivity is improved [80]. For this reason, Qin et al. [67] prepared PAF-PA5-Ag catalysts by surface hydroxyl modification of nano-silver using organics ( Fig. 7a-b). Compared to commercial Ag nanoparticles, the increased CO* adsorption strength on PAF-PA5-Ag due to the presence of OH groups and the inhibition of the HER reaction favored C-C coupling, which led to the selective generation of C2 products from CO2RR. In addition, *CHCOH is an important intermediate that stabilizes the C-O in *CHCOH due to the presence of interactions between the key intermediates and OH groups, which leads to the selective generation of EtOH from CO2RR. While it is well known that inhibition of intermediate deoxygenation is essential for CO2RR to generate ethanol. So, isn't increasing the surface oxygenophilicity of the catalyst more favorable for EtOH production? Wang et al. [26] prepared a Cu2O/Ag2.3 % catalyst by surface modification of Cu2O with Ag (Fig. 7c). And they found that Ag was activated and dispersed in the carrier during the CO2RR reaction. Eventually, the oxidation state and coordination number of Cu in the carrier were changed. The above alterations led to a change in the adsorption strength on the surface of the *CO catalyst, resulting in the formation of a unique adsorption structure. Ultimately, the asymmetric C-C coupling reaction was triggered, which led to an increase in ethanol yield (Fig. 7d). Higher deoxygenation barriers for key intermediates of *CHCOH can also improve the selectivity of ethanol [12]. For this reason, Wang et al. [49] improved the *CHCOH deoxygenation barrier by surface modification of Cu catalysts with nitrogen-doped carbon layers. The results of spectroscopic analysis showed that the domain-limiting effect of the nitrogen-doped carbon layer led to an increase in the electron passivation capacity and thus improved the deoxygenation barrier of the key intermediate of *CHCOH. Ultimately, the selectivity of ethanol was improved. 3.1.1.4 Surface engineering regulation-mass transfer enhancer Surface engineering regulation can be used to introduce other components to the catalyst surface to form a hierarchical porous structure [5,6,54]. The graded porous structure can maximize the specific surface area of the catalyst and fully expose the active components on the catalyst surface [54]. At the same time, the hierarchical porous structure can facilitate the transport of both electrons and electrolytes. Yang et al. [54] utilized this to integrate porous Cu with VO2 in graded porous nanomaterials ( Fig. 8a-c). The hierarchical porous structure of the Cu catalyst surface not only facilitates the transport of electrons and protons, but also the large specific surface area allows for sufficient dispersion of the active sites (Fig. 8d). Interestingly, the VO2-modified Cu catalyst surface was found to promote H2O dissociation by theoretical calculations. The resulting *H is more easily adsorbed on the catalyst surface thus promoting the protonation of key intermediates. And the catalyst reduces the C-C coupling energy barrier to some extent. Meanwhile, the enhanced adsorption of hydrogen protons on the catalyst surface inhibited the desorption of H2O to some extent. Ultimately, the breakage of the CC bond of *HCCOH was promoted (Fig. 8e-h). This inhibits the production of ethylene with a CC functional group and promotes the production of ethanol. In summary, surface engineering modulation changes the functional properties of catalysts in three ways. Firstly, the surface modification of organics makes the material with surface hydrophobicity so as to inhibit the HER competition reaction, and finally modulate the CO2RR product selectivity. This operation is helpful to improve the C2 product selectivity. But how precisely the C2 products including C2H4 and ETOH modulate the selectivity of EtOH needs further consideration. It is worth noting that modification of the catalyst with organics will cover the active sites of the catalyst to some extent. Therefore, the surface modification of organic matter should be considered from various aspects so as to achieve the optimal EtOH yield. Secondly, the key intermediate product for the formation of EtOH from CO2RR was stabilized by surface engineering conditioning, taking advantage of the collaborative effect between the catalyst and the modified organics. This operation can precisely control the generation of EtOH from CO2RR and greatly improve the selectivity of EtOH. However, the mechanism of the CO2RR reaction needs to be well understood, and at the same time, the problems mentioned above will also be encountered due to the involvement of organic substances. Thirdly, the surface structure of nanomaterials is altered by surface modulation engineering the second component of the primer. This operation is often used for porous materials to increase the catalyst's specific surface area, and the rich pore structure can increase the transport of electrons to the reaction medium. 3.1.1.5 Interface engineering regulation Interfacial engineering generally involves the formation of an interface between a pure metal component and another non-pure metal component (there is also an interface between pure metal grain boundaries), and the presence of this interface makes the catalyst exhibit different functional properties. Here, the catalysts are mainly classified into three kinds of functional properties ( Scheme 4): (i) local reaction environment effect, (ii) cascade reaction effect, and (iii) crystal aberrations effect. These three functional properties have different effects on the selective generation of EtOH from CO2RR. A detailed review of these three functional properties is given below. 3.1.1.6 Interface engineering regulation-local reaction environment effect The effect is usually a synergistic interaction between the unique structure of the catalyst itself (e.g., porous structure, hierarchical structure) resulting in a change in the local reaction environment (e.g., pH) and the interfaces formed by the different catalytically active centers, which facilitates the selective generation of EtOH from CO2RR. It is well known that the Cu0/Cu+ interface is able to promote C-C polymerization. It is also able to inhibit the production of C1 products, for which the selectivity of C2 products is improved [81–85]. For this reason, Kim et al. [51] synthesized Cu/Cu2O aerogels using a simple redox synthesis with abundant pore structure and a uniformly distributed Cu0-Cu+ interface ( Fig. 9a-b). Aerogels have a rich pore structure capable of causing a local pH increase effect. Comparative experiments revealed that the selectivity of ethanol was substantially increased with the local pH effect. It is well known that the increase of pH is unfavorable to the HER reaction [50]. While the porous structure of aerogel catalysts constitutes a semi-enclosed bounded space. Within this space pH is elevated and for this reason the HER side reaction is inhibited. At the same time, a large number of Cu0/Cu+ interfaces are distributed in the confined space, contributing to *CO enrichment. Eventually, the pH effect in the confined space combines with the *CO produced at the Cu0-Cu+ interfaces thus allowing the selective generation of EtOH (Fig. 9c). Meanwhile, electron and proton transport are crucial for the selective generation of EtOH from CO2RR. For this reason, Zang et al. [52] prepared Cu-N-G materials with a closed nano-space consisting of a Cu interface and an N-G interface by depositing N-G graphene onto the surface layer of Cu using the deposition method ( Fig. 10a). An interesting conclusion was confirmed by a combination of theoretical calculations and experiments. That is the intertwined N-G coated interface becomes a medium for charge transport. At the same time, the boundary effect of nano space enhances the adsorption of H on the catalyst surface. That is, the transfer of protons was enhanced. For this reason, the effective transfer of electrons and protons not only suppressed the HER side reaction but also enhanced the selectivity of the ethanol product (Fig. 10b-f). 3.1.1.7 Interface engineering regulation-cascade reaction effect Cascade catalytic systems are capable of efficiently linking the conversion of CO2 to CO and subsequent C-C coupling [86–88]. The effect is more dependent on the structure of the catalyst, which is mostly a core-shell structure, with the core acting as the initiator of the reaction and thus initiating a chain reaction from the core to the shell. The regulation of multiple components in the catalysts resulted in not only moderate CO adsorption sites but also improved C2+ selectivity [87]. It is considered an effective strategy to enhance the Faraday efficiency of C2+ (FEC2+). The cascade catalysts modulated by interfacial engineering tend to be core-shell catalysts. The core consists of pure metal active component fractions with high CO conversion (e.g., Ag, Au) while the shell layer mainly consists of Cu2O which easy for C-C coupling. Specific products can be induced from CO2RR through the interaction at the core-shell interface [76,89,90]. Among the many CO2RR catalysts, copper-based catalysts are currently the mainstream catalysts. This is mainly due to its moderate binding energy of key intermediates. For this reason, the selectivity of C2+ products can be improved [10,84]. However, copper-based catalysts with a single active component often suffer from low intermediate *CO production efficiency. For this reason, coordination of multiple intermediate active components is often required in practical CO2RR reactions. For this reason, Yu et al. [57] prepared a core-shell Ag@Cu2O catalyst ( Fig. 11a) using pure metal Ag core as the main active center for the generation of *CO and Cu2O as the shell layer. Experimentally, it was found that the selectivity of reactants was related to the number of layers of the shell (Fig. 11b) In the case of the smaller radius of the cavity and shell layer, CO2 could enter the Ag phase completely to generate *CO, and mono-CO was under-utilized to promote the HER reaction as well as part of the *CO overflow as shown in Path I. The two-layer structure of Ag@Cu2O catalysts was used to generate *CO in the Ag phase. As shown in reaction path I and reaction path II, the double-shell layer catalyst not only fully utilizes the *CO intermediate, but also inhibits the HER side reaction to some extent. Interestingly, is the appearance of C3 products when the number of shell layers of the catalyst is increased to three. This suggests that further increase in the number of shell layers enhances the C binding capacity to some extent. For this reason, the over-coverage of the silver phase by the shell layer leads to a blockage of *CO production. This facilitates the reaction on the shell layer as shown in pathways I-IV. Therefore, the number of shell layers affects the product selectivity to some extent. For this reason, an appropriate number of shell layers favors EtOH selective generation. Finite element simulation results further demonstrate that the appropriate number of catalyst shell layers can enrich the *CO intermediates (Fig. 11c). Thereby, the C-C coupling reaction is facilitated. Among the various active components of cascade catalysts, gold nanoparticles (Au NPs) attract attention. This is mainly due to their ability to effectively catalyze the formation of *CO intermediates from CO2. Thus, the coverage of *CO on the catalyst surface is improved [28,60,69]. For this reason, Zhang et al. [60] prepared catalysts with a core/shell interface ( Fig. 12) (Au core, Cu2O porous empty shell). Similar conclusions to Yu et al. were reached [57]. The Au catalyst core efficiently facilitates the conversion of CO2 to *CO. At the same time, the appropriate number of catalyst shell layers can enrich *CO. The final result is the efficient conversion of *CO to ethanol. 3.1.1.8 Interface engineering regulation-crystal aberrations effect The effect is mostly triggered by aberrant distortions on different crystal faces of a single catalyst. The grain boundaries induced by different crystal aberrations often have unique catalytic effects. With the development of theoretical calculations and the advancement of experimental techniques the study of grain boundaries (GBs) has been gradually deepened [87–90]. It has been found that copper GBS can be used as active sites for electrocatalytic CO2RR preparation of ethanol [91]. However, the detailed catalytic mechanism remains to be investigated. It is noteworthy that there are some unusual results when GBs are introduced on Cu(100). Such as enhanced adsorption of the key intermediate *CH3CHO and asymmetric geometric adsorption of *O. The above results contribute to the improvement of ethanol selectivity to some extent [89–91]. Cheng et al. [91] combined first-principles calculations and experiments to describe how GB modulates ethanol activity and selectivity. The experimental results show that GBs have two roles in the process of CO2RR. Firstly, they provide undercoordinated active sites. Secondly, elongated the Cu-Cu bond length ( Fig. 13a-c). These two important roles eventually stabilized the adsorption of the key intermediates *COOH and *CHO. Promoting the activation of CO2 and the protonation of *CO and the undercoordinated active sites near the GBs are able to stabilize *CH3CH2O while weakening *O adsorption (Fig. 13d-e). Ultimately, the selectivity of ethanol is improved. In summary, the interfacial modulation of catalysts containing monometallic active components changes the functional properties of catalysts in three main ways. Firstly, the boundary effect, which is mainly composed of the unique spatial structure of the catalyst and the interface of the catalyst, constitutes a synergistic effect. The existence of this microregion space has different effects (e.g., pH regulation in the region space, inhibition of H desorption in the region space, and thus inhibition of HER competition reaction). In contrast, C-C coupling reactions occur at interfaces consisting of different components in the catalyst. For this reason, the microregion creates a unique reaction environment for the interfacial reaction and thus enables the selective generation of EtOH from CO2RR. Secondly, the cascade effect often involves the generation of CO from the metal active component and subsequent CO enrichment at the metal/metal oxide interface for the coupling reaction. The presence of the metal active component compensates for the lack of *CO production and thus improves C2 selectivity. Combined with the interfacial reaction properties, the CO2RR selectivity can be improved to produce EtOH. In order to enrich CO on the reaction interface, most of the catalysts prepared are based on core-shell structure, and most of the metal active components are based on Ag and Au, which increases the complexity and cost of catalysts preparation to a certain extent. Thirdly, the study of the grain boundary effect is often dominated by pure metal Cu, whose coordination sites at the grain boundaries have a great relationship with the selective generation of EtOH from CO2RR. The study of the grain boundary effect requires extensive DFT calculations and more accurate and detailed experiments for verification. 3.1.1.9 Single-atom engineering regulation Current conventional CO2RR electrocatalysts have limitations in improving the faraday efficiency and current density of the product [92,93]. Single-atom catalysts (SAC) have attracted much attention in recent years due to their high atomic catalytic efficiency [94–96]. For example, single atom cobalt catalysts have ∼90 % HCOOH Faraday efficiency [94]. Nitrogen-doped carbon carrier-loaded monoatomic nickel catalysts have a d-state electron tunable property. This property can optimize the adsorption of key reaction intermediates on the catalyst surface. Thus, the CO2RR reaction performance is improved [95]. Currently, the Faraday efficiency of single-atom Cu catalysts using N-heterocyclic carbenes as carriers has reached 81 % for the generation of CH4 from CO2RR [96]. These above results fully demonstrate the great potential of SAC catalysis for electrocatalytic CO2RR. 3.1.1.10 Coordination number Heteroatoms coordinated with metal atoms can modulate the central charge density of the metal and fine-tune its binding strength to intermediates in the CO2 electroreduction process, which ultimately achieves a highly selective and high-yield synthesis of a certain target product. wang et al. [97] employed an organically linked ligand (1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) and In(NO3)·5 H2O to synthesize In-MOF, which was subsequently synthesized by physically mixing with dicyandiamide and then One-step pyrolysis was performed to obtain InA/NC with In-N4 structure. It was found by a combination of experimental and theoretical calculations that the In-N site of InA/NC not only favored the dissociation of COOH* to generate CO, but also hindered the generation of formate, which made its selectivity for CO higher than that for formate. At the same time, the reduction of hydrogen protons was also attenuated due to the structure of In-N4 maintaining an alkaline environment near the catalytic interface ( Fig. 14a-d). The Co-N site can also enhance the CO2RR selectivity by introducing additional N-ligand atoms. Pan et al. [98] prepared hollow nitrogen-doped carbon spheres by template method and obtained electrocatalysts with Co-N5 coordination configuration by impregnation of adsorbed cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc), where nitrogen atoms in the hollow nitrogen-doped carbon spheres acted as an additional nitrogen source to bond with the Co-N4 site in CoPc (Fig. 14e). In situ XANES characterization identified the catalytically active site as Co-N5. Theoretical calculations further explain the lower free energy of formation of *COOH at the Co-N5 site and the easier CO desorption. 3.1.1.11 Coordinating atom In addition to the coordination number, changing the ligand atomic species is another strategy to modulate the electrocatalytic activity of single atoms. The introduction of less electronegative atoms can well reduce the energy barrier of the CO2RR process intermediates and ultimately accelerate the kinetics of the reaction. In the carbon-based plane, the asymmetric Cu-S1N3 atomic interface has an optimized *COOH binding energy compared to the Cu-N4 site. In addition, the nearby Cu nanoparticles promoted the protonation process [100]. In addition, changing the ligand heteroatom species can also affect the reaction pathway to obtain different products. For example, SnN3O1 exhibits unique properties, and theoretical calculations have shown that the SnN3O1 conformation is able to lower the energy barriers for *COO activation and *COOH formation [101]. Zhang et al. [102] obtained a catalyst with Cu-O4 sites (Cu-DBC) by linking unit point Cu through MOF nodes, which showed a methane selectivity close to 80 %, with a partial current density of −203 mA/cm2 at −0. 9 V (vs. RHE). Under the same conditions, the Cu-O4 sites have lower CO2RR reaction energy barriers than Cu-N4 sites under the same conditions. NiN2-S, obtained by S doping NiN2, produces S vacancies under conditions of high overpotential application, and both S atoms and S vacancies have the effect of lowering the reaction energy barriers for CO2 generation from CO [103]. The majority of the studies mainly focus on the fine tuning of the coordination number of metal single atoms and the types of coordinating heteroatoms to regulate the adsorption and binding strength of the intermediates and achieve high selectivity of the target products. Although SAC have made good achievements in electrocatalytic CO2RR. However, we found that its products were mainly C1 products. The main reason for this result is the insufficient monoatomic active sites and the insufficient adsorption of key intermediates. This ultimately resulted in the difficulty of *CO dimerization. For this reason, efforts have been made in several aspects, such as the preparation of highly loaded single-atom catalysts thus adding more active sites, the control of the coordination environment of the metal center thereby improving product selectivity, and the introduction of multi-components thus enabling cascade reactions of single-atom catalysts. A detailed review of single atom engineering modulation for the generation of EtOH from CO2RR is presented below. Single-atom catalysts are generally loaded with active components onto a carrier, but a common problem faced by conventional preparation processes is the low loading of active groups, which results in a low catalytic activity due to an insufficient number of active sites. For this reason, Yang et al. [47] prepared ER-Cu/CuNC single atom catalysts (SACs) ( Fig. 15a) with high Cu loading by loading Cu onto honeycomb porous carbon using in situ electrochemical reduction (ER). The high Cu loading is more favorable for the construction of high-density Cu/CuNC interfacial sites with precise structures. The theoretical calculations revealed that the Cu/CuNC catalyst has excellent charge transfer ability, which is more favorable for the adsorption of *CO (Fig. 15b-d). Moreover, the high density of interfacial sites of Cu/CuNC significantly reduced the reaction barrier of *CO-*CHO coupling (Fig. 15e-f). For this reason, the prepared catalysts with a high density of Cu/CuNC interfacial sites exhibited high EtOH selectivity. The preparation of SAC with single high-density interfacial sites by in situ chemical oxidation is a relatively novel method for the preparation of monoatomic catalysts. The method opens up new avenues and provides new insights for the subsequent preparation of single-atom catalysts for the electrocatalytic CO2RR selective generation of EtOH. Tandem catalysts are newly emerging concepts. The coupling synergy between its active components can efficiently promote the preparation of C2+ products from electrocatalytic CO2RR [68]. Tandem catalysts catalyse the capture of CO2 to *CO on the one hand and the conversion of *CO to C2+ on the other hand through the division of labour between the active components. Ultimately, the Faraday efficiency (FE) of the product is increased [68]. Zhang et al. [68] prepared the single-atom catalyst CuO/Ni SAs+N-C with tandem effect by combining the tandem effect with single-atom engineering modulation from the departure of tandem catalysts. It was found by controlled experiments that the active components of the single-atom catalyst CuO/Ni SAs+N-C with tandem effect were uniformly distributed and in close proximity to each other ( Fig. 16a-c). And they also found that the closely adjacent nanostructures of this active component allowed Ni single atoms to be closely surrounded by Cu sites. The advantage of this tandem connection is reflected in two aspects. The first aspect is the production of *CO for the Ni single atom which increases the *CO concentration near the Cu sites. The second aspect is the ability of the neighboring Cu sites to rapidly convert *CO to C2+ products and thus increase the utilization of *CO. Notably, this unique structure allows for a continuous supply of *CO, thus eliminating the effect of reactant elimination mass on the rate of product generation (Fig. 16d-g). Ding et al. [104] utilized a cascade catalyst consisting of SnS2 nanosheets and monoatomic Sn to generate formic acid intermediates by CO2 reduction on SnS2 nanosheets, and on the monatomic Sn sites to generate bicarbonate intermediates and in situ C-C coupling to ethanol. It is shown that the selectivity of ethanol can be more than 70 % in a wide potential range from −0.6 to −1.1 VRHE. Meanwhile, the mechanism of CO2 reduction C-C coupling on monatomic Sn active centers is elucidated by combining isotope (13CO2 and H13COOH) labelling experiments and density functional theory studies. This study develops a new strategy for highly selective C-C coupling of CO2RR based on cascade catalysts, which further demonstrates the advantages of single-atom catalytic processes in the regulation of product selectivity and its potential in C-C coupling reactions. A full understanding of the coordination environments of monoatomic metal centers is instructive for their CO2RR selective reduction of EtOH. An in-depth study of the coordination environments of metal single atoms has been done by Lakshmanan [27] and Xia [46]. Lakshmanan et al. [27] prepared Fe single atom catalyst (Fe-n-f-CNTs) by ion exchange method. The Fe single atoms were found to be present in the catalyst in Fe-(O)3 coordination configuration by characterization. The unique Fe-(O)3 coordination configuration of the Fe single atom in the catalyst results in the continuous stabilization of the valence state of Fe at +3. Two advantages of this catalyst structural property have been found by density flooding calculations. The first reduces the reaction energy; the second induces electron transfer to the intermediates (*COOH and *OCHO), thus facilitating the generation of the key intermediate *CO. And they also found that the stabilization of the Fe active site benefited from the electrostatic effect of the carboxyl functional group on the CNT surface. Experimentally, it was found that the Fe single-atom active site was able to promote the instantaneous conversion of CO2 to *CO. Thus, the conversion of CO2 adsorbed on the surface of the CNT to C2 products was promoted. Briefly, the Fe single atoms were stabilized in the Fe-(O)3 coordination structure due to the electrostatic interaction of the functional groups on the CNT surface, thus exhibiting a high ethanol yield efficiency. N-doped C materials are able to anchor the active sites very well. For this reason, researchers anchored Cu into N-doped C materials to fabricate high-density Cu-Nx coordinated single-atom catalysts [46]. For example, Xia et al. [46] prepared N-doped C nanotube-loaded copper high-density single-atom catalysts (Cu-N-G) using mesoporous silica as a hard template. The catalyst has a Cu content of up to 13.35 wt%. The experimental results showed that the Cu-N-G single-atom catalyst was able to selectively electrocatalysis CO2RR for the preparation of ethanol. The main reason, thanks to the high density of Cu-N3 sites of Cu-N-G catalyst. Density-functional theory studies have shown that a high density of Cu-N3 is essential for the selective output of ethanol. Because, the high density of Cu-N3 sites shortens the distance between the active sites, thus facilitating the C-C coupling reaction. In summary, conventional catalysts have limitations for electrocatalytic CO2RR selective generation of EtOH. SACs as active, and selective electrocatalysts have the potential to break the limitations for CO2RR. However, there are some problems such as low loading, complicated preparation process and high cost. For this reason, simpler preparation methods with high loadings should be explored. Meanwhile, an in-depth understanding of the effect of the coordination environment of monatomic metal centres on the catalytic performance is crucial for the selective preparation of ethanol from CO2RR. 3.1.2 Catalysts containing pure metal active centers-multimetallic Compared with monometallic catalysts, bimetallic alloy catalysts are easier to regulate the surface electronic structure due to the synergistic interaction between the components. At the same time, the alloy interface is well dispersed on the catalyst surface which is favorable for generating more active sites [105,106]. Recent research results have shown that metal alloy catalysts regulate the adsorption strength of key intermediates on the catalyst surface by changing the electronic structure of the catalyst. This improves the product selectivity of electrocatalytic CO2RR [107–111]. At the same time, alloy catalysts can change the reaction energy barriers even through synergistic interactions between the components to promote the reaction. For example, bimetallic alloy catalysts (e.g., Ag-Cu [112–114], Ag-Zn [109], Sn-Zn [115], and Cu-Zn [116]) can increase the current density and reaction rate of CO2RR. The research progress of bimetallic-multimetallic alloy catalysts is reviewed in detail below in terms of interfacial engineering modulation, surface engineering modulation respectively. 3.1.2.1 Interfacial engineering regulation-interfacial electronic effects The excellent selectivity and catalytic activity of catalysts with multimetallic active centers is attributed to two factors: firstly, the interactions between the metal species form interfaces with active sites, and the interfacial stress influences the interactions of the intermediates; and secondly, the synergistic interaction between the metal species contributes to the regulation of the electronic structure of the catalyst surface. For example, Zhang et al. [117] demonstrated through theoretical calculations that the stress action between the Cu/Au interface enhances the interaction between *CHO and *CO thereby promoting the C-C coupling. Notably they also found that the energy required to generate ethanol at the Cu/Au interface was reduced. This further demonstrates that interfacial effects between metal species can reduce the energy barrier required for the reaction to some extent. It is well known that the catalytic activity of pure Cu catalysts for CO2RR to generate ethanol is not satisfactory. However, doping Ag into Cu promotes the selective generation of ethanol from CO2RR. The reason for this is not clear. To this end, Ting et al. [71] found two key factors for the ability of Ag-Cu catalysts to selectively promote ethanol production from CO2RR by both theoretical and experimental methods. Firstly, an Ag/Cu interface was formed on the surface of the Ag-Cu catalyst. The interface exists dual active sites to promote both the conversion of CO2 to *CO and the conversion of *CO to C2 products. Secondly, *CO is fully utilized. Activation of the selective ethanol production pathway is more favorable when the enriched *CO is rapidly and fully utilized. However, when the enriched *CO is not fully utilized, it is not conducive to the selective production of ethanol. Efforts have been made to increase the Faraday efficiency of electrocatalytic CO2RR to produce ethanol. Zhang et al. [70] prepared a catalyst combining a Cu-Zn alloy with Al oxides. It was found experimentally that the alloy and the oxide formed a tight interleaving forming a strong interaction. This led to the formation of a strong electronic effect between Cu-Zn-Al induced by Al2O3. A large number of metal-active interfaces were formed by the electronic effect thereby increasing the catalyst current density ( Fig. 17a). Further characterization revealed that the relative absorption intensity of *OCCOH on the surface of the Cu-Zn-Al catalyst was significantly enhanced, indicating that the C-C coupling process could be accelerated by the CuZn alloy phase. The subsequent *OCCOH hydrodeoxygenation step determines the selectivity of the C2+ products (C2H4, C2H5OH, CH3COOH and C3H7OH). 3.1.2.2 Surface engineering regulation-site synergy effects A hot topic in electrocatalytic CO2RR research is the selective generation of products. One of the main obstacles is the HER side reaction that seriously affects the selectivity of ethanol. The introduction of foreign components into the catalyst can form synergistic sites to promote the adsorption of *CO while inhibiting the adsorption of *H, thus inhibiting the HER side reaction and promoting C-C coupling. For example, Kim et al. [72] successfully prepared CuAgHg alloy catalyst films by doping Hg into CuAg catalysts. It was found through experiments and characterization that the adsorption of H atoms on the catalyst surface was inhibited due to the presence of Hg atoms in the catalyst, thus suppressing the HER side reactions. Meanwhile, they also found that the addition of Hg atoms inhibited the adsorption of H atoms on the catalyst surface while promoting the generation of CO2 to *CO. The catalyst surface was found to be enriched with *CO species by chemical detection and spectroscopic analysis. The combination of these two effects resulted in the selective generation of ethanol from CO2RR (Fig. 17b). Theoretical studies have revealed that the intermediate *CO-COH (often referred to as the selectivity-determining intermediate; SDI) is involved in the generation of either ethylene or ethanol. From this SDI, the ethylene pathway involves protonation and dehydration of Hads from the carbon closest to the electrode surface, whereas the ethanol pathway involves protonation of solvated protons on the carbon furthest away from the electrode surface, followed by detachment of the ethanol product (Fig. 17b). The increase in the selectivity of ethanol in the CO2RR is partly attributed to the decrease in the concentration of surface Hads. It is well known that C-C coupling is a key step in the generation of ethanol, however, C-C coupling reactions are often difficult to be carried out on the surface of monometallic catalysts [59]. The introduction of heteroatoms can couple to change the structure of monometallic catalysts and promote *CO enrichment while inhibiting the generation of H2 and C1 byproducts, thus improving the selectivity of ethanol. For example, Zhang et al. [59] prepared an AgCo alloy catalyst by ionic activation. Electrocatalytic CO2RR showed that the catalyst exhibited a high ethanol Faraday efficiency (73 %). Experimental and theoretical calculations revealed that the doping of Co atoms into Ag caused Ag lattice distortion thereby lowering the *CO2 δ-formation energy barrier. This further promotes the activation of CO2 to generate *CO. The further C-C coupling is facilitated by the large amount of *CO covering the catalyst surface, and the conversion to ethanol continues (Fig. 17c). It is noteworthy that site synergism not only inhibits the occurrence of side reactions but also promotes the generation of key intermediates at the active site. For example, Ren et al. [116] found that different sites on the surface of ZnCu alloy catalysts have different adsorption strengths for *CO by theoretical and experimental methods. The adsorption strength of *CO at Zn sites was weaker than that of *CO at Cu sites [118]. This result causes *CO to be susceptible to desorption at the Zn site and further interaction with intermediates (*CH2) adsorbed at the neighboring Cu site, resulting in the formation of key intermediates for ethanol production (*COCH2). The current study shows that Au in alloy catalysts plays a role in modifying the adsorption energy of key intermediates (e.g., *CH2CHO, *CH3CHO, and *CH3CH2O) on the surface of the catalyst [119]. This result is far-reaching for the improvement of electrocatalytic CO2RR activity and selectivity. For example, Shen et al. [61] prepared AuCu/Cu SCA alloy catalysts, and it was found experimentally that the AuCu/Cu SCA catalysts exhibited high catalytic stability as well as Faraday efficiency for ethanol. The enhanced selectivity of ethanol is mainly attributed to two points; firstly, Au acts as a co-catalyst and its introduction provides a sufficient amount of undercoordinated sites on the catalyst surface. Secondly, the adsorption of oxygenated intermediates on the catalyst surface was enhanced by the introduction of Au, which affected the selectivity of oxygenated products. It is noteworthy that Sn has a similar effect with Au in its ability to promote surface oxygenation of alloy catalysts. For example, Li et al. [62] found that Sn induced an increase in catalyst surface oxygenophilicity in Cu-Sn bimetallic catalysts, thereby promoting the protonation of oxygenated intermediates to produce ethanol. 3.1.2.3 Interfacial engineering regulation -structural sensitivity effects Structure-sensitive effects refer to the different catalytic effects exhibited by catalysts when prepared into different structures. Different structures usually expose unique crystal surfaces, and the crystal surface effect affects the adsorption of intermediates to some extent [58]. For example, Lyengar et al. [58] prepared Cucub-Ag and Cuoh-Ag catalysts by doping Ag into Cu nanocubes (Cucub) and Cu octahedra (Cuoh), respectively ( Fig. 18a-d). The experimental results showed that Cuoh-Ag has high ethanol selectivity. The reason for this was found that Ag as a co-catalyst was able to produce abundant *CO species near the Cuoh active site. Meanwhile, Cuoh in Cuoh-Ag consists of (111) crystal facets which are conducive to the promotion of the *CHx-*CO coupling reaction, which is a key step in the generation of ethanol (Fig. 18e-h). Nanowires as a unique catalyst structure can facilitate the transport of substances. The preparation of catalysts into nanowire-like structures applied to electrocatalytic CO2RR can obtain excellent performance [69]. For example, Zhu et al. [69] prepared CuxAuy alloy catalysts into nanowire structures using electrodeposition. It was found that the unique nanowire structure accelerated mass transfer, resulting in an increase in pH and *CO concentration near the catalyst. In addition, the electronic structure of the catalyst surface could be appropriately altered by adjusting the components of the CuxAuy nanowires, which further facilitated the generation of ethanol by C-C coupling. This experiment fully demonstrated the feasibility of component synergy and structure effect for electrocatalytic CO2RR preparation of ethanol. 3.2 Catalysts without pure metal active centers As shown in Table 2, catalysts without pure metal active components are mainly classified into two types: the first one is metal oxide catalysts, in which the active components are partly derived from metal oxides. Metal oxides, especially copper oxide, are considered ideal catalysts for electrocatalytic CO2RR due to their moderate intermediate adsorption energy [120]. However, single CuO catalysts often suffer from low electrical conductivity and insufficient *CO concentration on the catalyst surface, for which a common approach is to prepare loaded metal oxide catalysts by composite with C-based carriers [121,122]. At the same time, metal oxides are not only active components in catalysts, it also plays very important role in dispersion of active centers in catalysts [123,124]. Another type of catalyst is the metal sulfide catalyst. Sulfides are easily enriched with sulfur vacancies by treatment due to the presence of elemental sulfur in the sulfide. The electronic effect of the S vacancies has been shown to be beneficial in improving the selectivity of electrocatalytic CO2RR for the preparation of ethanol [123,125]. Notably, regardless of the catalysts, they all share the common property of using the electronic effect to stabilize Cu δ+, thereby promoting the selective generation of EtOH from CO2RR [124–127]. Recent results have shown that Cuδ+ (0<δ<1) can interact with electrons around C atoms thereby lowering the C-C coupling energy barrier [71]. Additionally, the formation process of Cuδ+ is a dynamic process and is generally unstable [134,135]. Therefore, the preparation of abundant and stable Cuδ+ active sites is crucial for the electrocatalytic CO2RR preparation of ethanol. The factors affecting the selective generation of EtOH from CO2RR by these two types of catalysts and the corresponding engineering regulation are reviewed in detail below. 3.2.1 Metal oxide 3.2.1.1 Stabilization of Cuδ+ species The present study shows that there are two non-negligible problems in the electrocatalytic CO2RR preparation of ethanol, especially for copper-based catalysts [128]. Firstly, the reaction of electrolysis of water to precipitate oxygen occurs during electrocatalysis, and the oxygen produced oxidizes the active sites of the catalyst. Secondly, as mentioned above Cuδ+ (0<δ<1) is considered to be the key active site of Cu-based catalysts, which is capable of promoting C-C coupling reactions. However, Cuδ+ is highly susceptible to reduction to Cu0 thereby drastically reducing the activity of the catalyst. CeO2 has been used to modulate the active sites of catalysts due to its abundant oxygen vacancy content, and stable face center cubic structure [4,5]. Thus, the problem of unstable catalysts prone to deactivation is solved [129]. For example, Tian et al. [129] prepared a CuO/CeO2 catalyst by compositing CeO2 with CuO. Experiments showed that CeO2 acted as a co-catalyst in which the oxygen vacancies facilitated the adsorption and activation of CO2 to promote the C-C coupling reaction. In addition, the electron-donating property of Ce3+ in CeO2 can inhibit the reduction of Cuδ+ to Cu0, which ensures the stability of the catalyst activity. As already mentioned, the selective reduction of CO2RR to EtOH can be promoted by regulating the reaction conditions by pulsed potentials. In addition, the catalyst is reduced during the electrochemical reduction process thereby decreasing its activity. Notably, Timoshenko et al. [121] used pulsed potentials to balance the content of copper in the reduced and oxidized states in CuO. The experimental results demonstrated that the dynamic balance between the oxidation and reduction states of Cu in CuO enabled the catalyst to exhibit excellent ethanol selectivity ( Fig. 19a-d). It is well known that the modulation of the electronic structure of metal oxides by catalyst carriers is a commonly used modulation strategy. The special coordination structure formed between the catalyst carrier and the oxide thereby modulates the adsorption of intermediates [122]. For example, Su et al. [122] prepared CuO-N-C catalysts by loading CuO onto N-doped C carriers. The experimental results showed that the Cu atoms of CuO bonded with the N atoms of the catalyst carrier to form CuN3 clusters during the electrocatalytic CO2RR (Fig. 19e). The N atoms in the CuN3 clusters regulated the electronic structure of the Cu atoms, and the CuN3 clusters formed charge-asymmetric adsorption sites thereby enhancing the adsorption of *CH3, which was favorable for the formation of ethanol. Notably, Cu+ species may facilitate the C-C coupling step [136,131,132], however, Cu-based materials, especially Cu-based oxide materials, especially Cu-based oxides, are inevitably electrochemically reduced at negative potentials [133]. Another reason why stabilization and tuning of the key intermediate (*CO2-CO Another reason why stabilization and tuning of the key intermediate (*HOCCH) would make the * HOCCH to the hydrogenation-generation pathway (the ethanol pathway) rather than the dehydroxylation pathway) rather than the dehydroxylation pathway from *HOCCH to *CCH (ethylene pathway). This is important for determining the Faraday energy Faraday efficiency of ethanol and ethylene. The Faraday efficiency of ethylene is crucial. Wang et al. [129], prepared a CuOx@C catalyst with a carbon shell by one-pot pyrolysis of the copper-based metal-organic skeleton HKUST-1 (Cu3(BTC)2, Cu-BTC). The catalyst showed high selectivity for CO2 electroreduction to ethanol with a Faraday efficiency of 46 %. CuOx@C was coated with a homogeneous carbon layer ( Fig. 20a), which effectively stabilized the Cu+ substance under CO2 electroreduction conditions, thus facilitating the C-C coupling step. The stabilized Cu+ substance facilitates CO formation at low current densities and promotes C-C coupling at high current densities. Density-functional theory (DFT) calculations indicate that the abundant Cu+ matter is mainly responsible for C-C coupling by improving *CO adsorption, and that the surface carbon layer can effectively regulate the hydrogenation pathway of the key intermediate *HOCCH into ethanol production (Fig. 20b-e). 3.2.1.2 Carbon dioxide molecular activation As a heat-stable molecule that is difficult to activate, the standard electrode potential required to efficiently convert CO2 molecules into CO2 -anionic species in aqueous solution is −1.9 V vs RHE under standard conditions. Therefore, how to efficiently activate CO2 has become the key in the CO2 electrocatalytic reduction reaction. Usually, the efficient transfer of electrons to CO2 molecules is considered to be the key step in the activation of CO2 molecules, so the catalyst surface with a large number of electrons and efficiently transferring them to the surface of CO2 molecules is an important process for the activation of CO2 molecules. The rational design of a catalyst with a large number of electron-active centers and efficient activation of CO2 molecules is an effective way to solve this bottleneck in the current CO2 electrochemical reduction reaction. Recently, oxygen vacancies have been used as an important means to improve the catalytic performance of catalysts for CO2 molecules in their heterogeneous catalytic systems. The fundamental reason is that the modulation of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface can effectively regulate the electronic structure of the catalyst surface, enhance the electron enrichment effect on the catalyst surface, and efficiently achieve the activation of CO2 molecules by single electron transfer process. For example, the introduction of oxygen vacancy defects on the surface of titanium dioxide produces highly stable adsorption configurations and stronger activation of CO bonds. Thereby, leading to the exothermic dissociation of carbon dioxide with a potential barrier of 22.2 kcal mol−1 [137]. In addition, oxygen vacancies decorated on BiOCl nanometres also lead to exothermic dissociation of carbon dioxide. Vacancies decorated on BiOCl nanoplates give an electron-rich electron-enriched surface, which can act as electron trap centres to convert CO2 into CO2 - through a single electron transfer process [138]. Guided by DFT calculations, Geng et al. [139] developed oxygen vacancy-rich ZnO nanosheets as efficient catalysts for the electrochemical reduction of CO2 using a simple H2 plasma etching method. During the electrochemical reduction of CO2, the oxygen vacancy-rich ZnO nanosheets were efficiently reduced to CO products with a current density as high as −16.1 mA/cm2 at a voltage of −1.1 V vs RHE, while their Faraday efficiency was as high as about 83 %. Mechanistic studies further indicated that the oxygen defect structure on the surface of the 2D thin-layer ZnO could effectively enhance the activation of CO2, thereby improving the performance of the ZnO catalyst for the electrochemical catalytic reduction reaction of CO2 ( Fig. 21). 3.2.2 Metal sulfide 3.2.2.1 Stabilization of Cuδ+ species Recent results have shown that a high overpotential (∼1.0) is required for the electrocatalytic CO2RR selective generation of ethanol. However, excessive overpotentials not only result in energy loss but also exacerbate the production of formate as a side product [140–144]. In general, the main reason for high overpotential is that the C-C coupling reaction is not easy to carry out (positively charged C atoms repel each other, preventing the reaction from proceeding) [38,125,145]. It has been shown that Cuδ+(0<δ<1) is able to regulate the electrons carried by C, thus promoting C-C coupling [145–148]. Therefore, involving stable Cuδ+ in regulating C-C coupling to improve ethanol selectivity is an ideal strategy. It has been shown that the introduction of electron-rich and easily doped S atoms not only alters the electronic structure of monatomic sites, but also creates defects on the substrate [10,149–153], thus improving the stability of the active sites [135,154–158]. Guo et al. [126] prepared nano cubic catalysts (Cu2S1-xHN) rich in S vacancies using in situ electrocatalytic reduction ( Fig. 22a-c). Exhibiting a very low overpotential of −0.19 V in ethanol production, the catalyst not only exhibited 86.9 % ethanol selectivity and 73.3 % faraday efficiency but also provided long-term stability of Cuδ+, which was obtained on the basis of techno-economic analyses (Fig. 22d-e). In the C-C coupling step that determines the potential, the applied potential is brought close to the theoretical value due to the reduced reaction barrier (Fig. 22f-h). DFT calculations further corroborate that the presence of the S vacancy modulates the electronic structure of the Cu species making the Cuδ+ stable, which ultimately leads to the excellent catalytic performance of the prepared catalysts. The basic step of CO2RR involves multiple co-operative proton-electron transfer (CPET) steps. It has been found that monovalent Cu(I) in copper-based electrodes facilitates the binding of moderately strong *CO [4]. Nevertheless, the instability of Cu(I) remains a challenge to maintain high catalytic activity. On the other hand, the formation of C-C bonds by coupling to form *OCHCHO* has a lower energy barrier compared to the reaction path of forming *OCHCHO* by direct coupling via *CHO. [159]. However, the most dangerous reaction pathway is the formation of CHO intermediates via hydrogenation of CO is the rate-limiting step in the formation of the key *OCHCHO* intermediate during the conversion of CO2 to ethanol [160]. This suggests that the simultaneous stabilization of protons and CO intermediates is important for the conversion of CO2 to ethanol. The simultaneous stabilization of protons and CO intermediates is important for the formation of CHO intermediates [161] and the subsequent C-C coupling step. Meanwhile, indium-based electrodes (e.g., In2S3) have been reported to contribute to the activation of water and exhibit stable adsorption, and they act as proton donors in the CO2RR process [162]. Therefore, the introduction of In elements facilitate proton trapping [162]. To this end, Wen et al. [163] stabilised active Cu(I) and In double sites with sulphury defects via an electrically driven intercalation strategy, which led to electron density delocalization and thus enhanced orbital hybridization between Cu-C and In-H bonds. As a result, the energy barrier of the rate-limiting *CHO formation step in ethanol production is lowered to the critical *OCHCHO* formation, which also benefits from combined Cu sites capable of C-C coupling and In sites with higher oxygen affinity based on both ( Fig. 23). 3.2.2.2 Exposure active site To date, a variety of two-dimensional electrocatalysts, such as oxides and metal-sulfur compounds, have been reported for use in electrocatalytic CO2RR. Among them, metal-sulfur compounds have attracted much attention due to their fascinating physical, chemical and electronic properties [164]. Compared to binary metal-sulfur compounds, ternary metal-sulfur compounds can often exhibit unique reaction mechanisms and/or enhanced electrocatalytic activity due to the synergistic interaction between two different metals, as in the case of bimetallic [165]. Sun et al. [166] found that methanol can be produced on Mo-Bi bimetallic sulfide nanosheets via electrocatalytic CO2RR, due to the synergistic Mo and Bi effect. Wang et al. reported that the synergistic effect of Cu and Sn atoms promoted higher affinity between the reaction intermediates and the cations in Cu, thus enhancing the electrocatalytic activity [167]. However, studies related to ternary metal sulphide nanosheets for CO2RR are still in their infancy. Hexagonal ZIS with a layered structure is a typical direct bandgap semiconductor that has been widely used in photocatalytic and electrocatalytic CO2RR [168–173]. Meanwhile, ultrathin ZIS nanosheets with abundant Zn vacancies and ZIS microspheres assembled from the nanosheets were demonstrated for electrochemical reduction of CO2 to formate [173]. However, the reported reduction products are usually C1 species. Considering that nitrogen-doped carbon can increase CO2 adsorption, promote electron transfer and activate active sites. For this reason, Cai et al. [174] synthesized ultrathin ZIS nanosheet arrays (ZIS NSAs) grown on N-doped carbon cloth (NDCC) via a simple hydrothermal route ( Fig. 24). The synthesized ZIS NSAs/NDCC-enabled electrocatalytic CO2 exhibited, for 42 % ethanol Faraday efficiency (FE) at −0.7 V applied potential. Experimental results and density-functional theory (DFT) calculations showed that NDCC could increase the *CO content thereby promoting the CO-CO coupling process in CO2RR. Two-dimensional (2D) ultrathin nanosheet electrocatalysts are rich in surface active sites, exhibit better electrical conductivity along 2D conducting channels, and reduce the activation energy barrier of CO2, which makes them promising for applications in efficient CO2RR. However, due to van der Waals forces between 2D ultrathin nanosheets, they tend to aggregate. The direct growth of these 2D ultrathin nanosheets on conductive carriers not only maintains a large surface area and inhibits the aggregation of active sites, but also reduces the contact resistance, which promotes electron transfer. In conclusion, stable Cuδ+ is essential for ethanol selectivity. As far as metal oxides are concerned, complexation with other metal oxides rich in oxygen vacancies is the ideal strategy. As for sulfides, the construction of S-rich vacancies by appropriate preparation methods is also an ideal strategy for Cuδ+. The construction of 2D materials has received increasing attention because of (1) high surface-to-volume ratios to maximize atomic utilization; (2) a large number of low-coordination atoms acting as catalytically active sites; and (3) the thickness of the atomic layer that reduces the carrier migration distance and facilitates electron transfer. 2D nanosheets are characterized by a large number of exposed surface atoms, which can easily escape from the lattice to form vacancy defects. 2D nanosheets are usually accompanied by the formation of disordered structures during the synthesis process, and such defects reduce the coordination number of surface atoms, which in turn promotes the chemisorption of reactants and improves the catalytic performance. 3.2.3 Surface engineering modulation of non-metallic elements Modification of copper-based catalysts based on non-metallic elements is an effective strategy to enhance the activity of catalysts and catalytic electrodes for the reduction of CO2 to produce ethanol. The introduction of non-metallic elements (e.g., nitrogen, boron, sulphury, etc.) can change the electronic structure of the copper-based catalysts and improve the stability and activity of the catalysts. Non-metallic doping can also increase the acidity and alkalinity of the catalyst surface, which is conducive to the adsorption and activation of CO2, thus improving the conversion of ethanol. Professor Sargent's group has carried out extensive research in this direction of modification, which has pushed forward the development of Cu-based catalysts doped with non-metallic elements in terms of their performance and modification mechanism [175–177]. In 2018, the group [175] used Cu3N nano- spheres as the substrate material and used electrochemical reduction treatment to generate a Cu spherical shell layer structure on the surface of the nanospheres.
