The presence of the internal nuclear structure Cu3N changed the electronic structure of the metal Cu in the shell layer, which in turn affected the adsorption and dimerization of the intermediate CO in the CO2 reduction process, and inhibited the reduction of the Cu+ intermediate state. In the same year, Sargent's group synthesized Cu nanorods doped and modified with different B contents in a one-step process by using NaBH4 as the reducing agent and B source [176]. In this catalyst, the introduction of B modulates the average oxidation state of the base copper, which in turn directly affects the adsorption and dimerization of the intermediate product CO, resulting in a high selectivity of the C2 product. The experimental results showed that the Faraday efficiency of the C2 product reached 79 % ± 2 % when the average valence state of Cu in the B-doped Cu catalyst was +0.35, which was a significant improvement, and the reaction could be stabilized for about 40 h. On the basis of the previous studies, the group has started to try to explore the modification mechanism by using more non-metallic elements in the doping of Cu with metals. Ma et al. [178] investigated a variety of halogen ion-modified Cu catalysts, and found that fluorine (F) ion-modified Cu catalysts (F-Cu) showed ultra-high C2+ product selectivity, with FEC2+ up to 85.8 % and a one-way yield of 16.5 %, which achieved a new breakthrough in the production of ethylene and ethanol by CO2 electrocatalytic reduction. Through in situ characterization techniques and theoretical calculation simulations, the researchers revealed that F ions can effectively activate water molecules, enhance the adsorption of intermediate product *CO and the reaction strength of adsorbed *CO hydrogenation to generate CHO intermediates, and lower the energy barrier of molecular coupling reaction, thus enhancing the selectivity of C2+ products. Su et al. [179] developed a nitrogen-doped Cu-based catalyst that achieved 72 % Faraday efficiency for C2+ products and 51 % Faraday efficiency for ethanol at a potential of −1.1 V vs. RHE. The above results of doping of various nonmetallic elements showed that the doping of nonmetallic ions can promote the selectivity of ethanol or C2+ products in terms of stabilizing Cu+, stabilizing the reaction intermediates, and lowering the reaction energy barriers, which provides a new way of thinking for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. 4 Summary and outlook In summary, we present recent advances in engineering modulation of catalyst materials for electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction to ethanol. The engineering modulation of catalysts is mainly divided into four aspects: engineering modulation of reaction conditions, surface engineering modulation, interfacial engineering modulation, and single-atom engineering modulation. The engineering control of reaction conditions mainly includes the influence of reaction conditions such as the type of electrolyte added, pH of the reaction medium, applied potential, temperature, etc. on the catalysts for selective catalysis of CO2RR for the preparation of EtOH. The surface engineering modification mainly promotes the selective preparation of EtOH from CO2RR through three kinds of functional properties: firstly, the surface modification of organic materials makes the materials with surface hydrophobicity, thus inhibiting the HER competition reaction, and ultimately adjusting the selectivity of CO2RR products. Secondly, the surface engineering modifications exploit the synergistic effect between catalyst and surface modified organics to stabilize the key intermediates of CO2RR for the production of EtOH. This operation was able to precisely control the generation of EtOH from CO2RR and substantially improve the selectivity of EtOH. Thirdly, the surface structure of nanomaterials is modified by surface modulation of the second component of the engineered primer. This operation is often used for porous materials to increase the specific surface area of the catalyst, and the rich pore structure can increase the electron transport to the reaction medium. Interfacial engineering modulation generally involves the formation of an interface between a pure metal component and another non-pure metal component (and also between pure metal grain boundaries), the presence of which results in the catalyst exhibiting different functional properties. Here, the catalysts are mainly classified into three kinds of functional properties: (i) local reaction environment effect, (ii) cascade reaction effect, and (iii) crystal aberrations effect. These three functional properties are used to facilitate the selective preparation of EtOH from CO2RR in different ways. The current CO2RR electrocatalysts have limitations in terms of increasing the current density, Faraday efficiency (FE) of the desired products, and the durability of the catalysts. Single-atom catalysts, with their efficient source utilization and fully exposed active site centers, are promising to improve the catalytic bottleneck of conventional catalysts. For this reason, single-atom modulation engineering may be a promising but challenging approach to achieve C-C coupling in electrochemical CO2RR. The catalysts prepared by the above four engineering modulations were useful in different aspects for the generation of EtOH from CO2RR. Therefore, it is important to understand the key factors affecting the catalyst activity by different engineering modulations and to apply a combination of engineering modulations to the catalyst development. At the same time, some issues to be considered and challenges to be overcome were identified through the study of the reviewed engineering modulation catalysts. The solution of these problems and challenges is of great importance to further improve the selectivity of CO2RR for the generation of EtOH. 1. Surface modification by organics made the material’s surface hydrophobic thereby inhibiting the HER competition reaction and ultimately tuning up the CO2RR product selectivity. This operation is helpful to improve the C2 product selectivity, but the C2 products including C2H4 and EtOH are more limited if the selectivity improvement is accurate to EtOH. It is worth noting that modification of the catalyst with organics will cover the active sites of the catalyst to some extent. Therefore, the surface modification of the organics should be considered from various aspects to achieve the optimal EtOH yield. 2. In-depth study of the reaction mechanism of catalysts in the reaction process. Explore the main active sites of catalysts and the catalytic mechanisms. Integration of experiments with isotope labelling is required for a detailed study of the reaction mechanism. At the same time the combination of theoretical calculations and experiments provides a deeper understanding of the surface reactions of catalysts. 3. Electrocatalytic CO2 preparation of ethanol is a proton and electron transfer reaction, for which water becomes a highly desirable reaction medium. However, due to the low solubility of CO2, the occurrence of HER side reactions can be increased, and a large amount of energy can be lost. Therefore, the urgent problem is to increase the solubility of CO2 in water. 4. An in-depth study of key intermediates in the pathway to ethanol preparation by electrocatalytic CO2RR. This requires a combination of isotope characterization, theoretical calculations as well as experiments. The use of some in-situ characterization (e.g., in-situ infrared spectroscopy, in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy, etc.) is also essential for the study of key intermediates. 5. Single-atom catalysts prepared by single-atom engineering regulation are expected to solve the bottleneck problem of traditional catalysts. However, the major problems of single-atom catalysts are the low density of active sites and the high cost of the complicated preparation process. Therefore, high active density monatomic catalysts should be prepared by reducing the preparation cost and simplifying the preparation process of single-atom catalysts. 6. Machine learning (ML) has been heavily used to screen catalysts. However, current machine learning methods are limited to exploring a narrow chemical space with certain limitations. For this reason, over the combination of ML models and CO2RR selectivity distribution maps to establish a high-throughput screening method and to achieve the screening of CO2RR catalysts to develop catalysts with excellent performance, which was validated by experimental methods is a promising strategy. 7. Electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction (CO2RR) is a promising carbon conversion technology as it can convert CO2 into high value-added C2+ fuels at ambient temperature and pressure without additional carbon emissions. However, due to the high structural stability and chemical inertness of CO2 molecules, as well as their low water solubility and diffusivity in the aqueous phase, the CO2 supply near the catalytic site in the CO2RR process is often insufficient, which leads to the low reaction rate, selectivity and stability, and seriously limits the industrial application of CO2RR for the production of C2+ fuels. Enrichment is to make the concentration of a certain component in the matrix higher than the other components by some means. Through the rational design of catalysts, regulation of electrolyte and optimization of electrolytic devices, CO2 molecules can be enriched near the catalytic site, which will lead to an increase in the percentage of activated molecules per unit volume and an increase in the effective collision between molecules, and thus accelerate the reaction rate; through the modification of atoms on the catalyst surface, including the construction of grain boundaries, the introduction of crystal boundaries, and the introduction of a crystal boundary, the reaction rate of CO2 is accelerated. By modifying the catalyst surface atoms, including the construction of grain boundaries, the introduction of defects and vacancies, and the modulation of the electrolyte composition, the bonding of key intermediates (*CO, *COOH, *OCHO, *CH2CHO, *CH3CHO, and *CHO) to the catalyst surface can be enhanced, and the adsorption of the key intermediates on the catalyst surface can be facilitated to improve the selectivity of the CO2RR in the production of C2+ products. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic CO2RR is an ideal method. It is capable of converting CO2 into usable fuels and valuable chemical products. Electrocatalytic CO2RR produces a wide range of chemicals. Of these, ethanol (EtOH) is favored for its wide industrial and commercial value. However, electrocatalytic CO2RR preparation of EtOH involves C-C coupling reactions and is a multi-electron transfer process. For this reason, the efficient electrochemical conversion of EtOH by CO2RR remains a great challenge. The preparation of EtOH by electrocatalytic CO2RR involves the interference of a competing hydrogen evolution reaction as well as some other reaction intermediates. This limits the improvement of Faraday efficiency of ethanol (FEEtOH) and the current density of ethanol (JEtOH). To improve ethanol selectivity, the researchers designed and modified the catalysts using engineering regulation effects such as reaction conditions engineering regulation, surface engineering regulation, interfacial engineering regulation, and single atom engineering regulation, and achieved excellent results. Therefore, it is important to understand the key factors affecting the catalyst activity by different engineering regulations and to apply a combination of engineering regulations to the catalyst development. Therefore, this paper firstly provides a comprehensive summary of the catalysts applied for the preparation of EtOH by electrocatalytic CO2RR, including two major categories of catalysts containing pure metal active components and catalysts without pure metal active components. Subsequently, the main effects of engineering modulation on catalyst activity are analyzed and summarized in detail, respectively. Finally, the future challenges and development prospects of electrocatalytic CO2RR for EtOH preparation were highlighted.
